# Planning, Budgeting and Forecasting

Part 1B covers **planning and control** processes.

slides.title: Budgeting Methods
slides.content:
# Budget Approaches

## Top-Down vs Bottom-Up

| Approach | Characteristics |
|----------|----------------|
| Top-down | Management sets |
| Bottom-up | Departments propose |
| Participative | Combined |

## Incremental Budgeting

```
Last year's budget
+/- Adjustments
= New budget
```

## Zero-Based Budgeting

- Start from zero
- Justify all expenditures
- Decision packages
- Ranking

## Activity-Based Budgeting

- Identify activities
- Cost drivers
- Link costs to output

slides.title: Flexible Budgets
slides.content:
# Flexible Budgeting

## Static vs Flexible

| Static | Flexible |
|--------|----------|
| One activity level | Multiple levels |
| Fixed | Adjusts |

## Flexible Budget Formula

```
Total Cost = Fixed Cost + (Variable Rate x Activity)
```

## Example

```
Budget: 10,000 units
Actual: 12,000 units

Variable cost per unit: $5
Fixed costs: $50,000

Flexible budget:
$50,000 + ($5 x 12,000) = $110,000
```

## Benefits

- Fair comparison
- Isolate efficiency
- Better control

slides.title: Forecasting Methods
slides.content:
# Forecasting Techniques

## Qualitative Methods

| Method | Description |
|--------|-------------|
| Executive opinion | Management judgment |
| Delphi | Expert consensus |
| Market research | Customer surveys |
| Sales force | Field estimates |

## Quantitative Methods

| Method | Approach |
|--------|----------|
| Moving average | Smoothing |
| Exponential smoothing | Weighted |
| Regression | Relationships |
| Time series | Patterns |

## Regression Analysis

```
Y = a + bX

Y = Dependent variable
a = Intercept
b = Slope
X = Independent variable
```

slides.title: Sales Forecasting
slides.content:
# Sales Projections

## Factors to Consider

| Internal | External |
|----------|----------|
| Capacity | Economy |
| Marketing | Competition |
| Pricing | Regulations |
| Historical | Demographics |

## Trend Analysis

```
Step 1: Identify trend
Step 2: Calculate growth rate
Step 3: Project forward
Step 4: Adjust for factors
```

## Seasonal Adjustments

```
Seasonal index = Period sales / Average sales

Adjusted forecast = Base x Seasonal index
```

## Sales Mix

- Product mix percentages
- Weighted average contribution

slides.title: Pro Forma Statements
slides.content:
# Financial Projections

## Pro Forma Income Statement

```
Projected Revenue
- Projected COGS
= Projected Gross Profit
- Projected Operating Exp
= Projected Operating Income
```

## Pro Forma Balance Sheet

| Approach | Method |
|----------|--------|
| Percent of sales | Items as % of revenue |
| Specific estimates | Line by line |

## Additional Funds Needed

```
AFN = (A/S x Change in S)
    - (L/S x Change in S)
    - (PM x S1 x RR)

A/S = Assets to sales
L/S = Liabilities to sales
PM = Profit margin
RR = Retention ratio
```

slides.title: Cash Budgeting
slides.content:
# Cash Budget

## Structure

```
Beginning cash balance
+ Cash receipts
- Cash disbursements
= Ending cash balance

If below minimum:
= Financing required
```

## Cash Receipts

| Source | Timing |
|--------|--------|
| Cash sales | Immediate |
| Collections | Based on pattern |
| Other income | As received |

## Collection Pattern

```
Month of sale: 20%
Month after: 50%
Two months after: 28%
Uncollectible: 2%
```

## Cash Disbursements

- Purchases
- Payroll
- Operating expenses
- Capital expenditures

slides.title: Variance Analysis
slides.content:
# Performance Variances

## Types of Variances

| Category | Measures |
|----------|----------|
| Revenue | Price, volume |
| Material | Price, usage |
| Labor | Rate, efficiency |
| Overhead | Spending, volume |

## Material Variances

```
Price Variance:
(Actual price - Standard price) x Actual qty

Usage Variance:
(Actual qty - Standard qty) x Standard price
```

## Favorable vs Adverse

| F (Favorable) | A (Adverse) |
|--------------|-------------|
| Better than budget | Worse than budget |
| Increases profit | Decreases profit |

slides.title: Labor and Overhead Variances
slides.content:
# Labor Variances

## Labor Rate Variance

```
(Actual rate - Standard rate) x Actual hours
```

## Labor Efficiency Variance

```
(Actual hours - Standard hours) x Standard rate
```

## Overhead Variances

### Variable Overhead

```
Spending: Actual - (Actual hrs x Std rate)
Efficiency: (Actual - Std hrs) x Std rate
```

### Fixed Overhead

```
Spending: Actual - Budgeted
Volume: (Actual - Budgeted units) x Rate
```

slides.title: Variance Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: If actual hours exceed standard hours, the labor efficiency variance is?

slides.title: Sales Variances
slides.content:
# Revenue Variances

## Sales Price Variance

```
(Actual price - Budget price) x Actual units
```

## Sales Volume Variance

```
(Actual units - Budget units) x Budget contribution
```

## Sales Mix Variance

```
(Actual mix - Budget mix) x Budget contribution x Actual total
```

## Sales Quantity Variance

```
(Actual total - Budget total) x Budget avg contribution
```

## Interpretation

- Price: Selling price differences
- Volume: Total units differences
- Mix: Product proportion changes

slides.title: Rolling Forecasts
slides.content:
# Continuous Planning

## Rolling Forecasts

```
Continuously updated:
Month 1 ends -> Add Month 13

Always looking 12 months ahead
```

## Benefits

| Advantage | Description |
|-----------|-------------|
| Current | Always up to date |
| Flexible | Adapts to changes |
| Forward-looking | Future focus |

## Beyond Budgeting

| Principle | Meaning |
|-----------|--------|
| Relative targets | Beat competitors |
| Adaptive planning | Rolling forecasts |
| Resources on demand | Not fixed |

slides.title: Sensitivity Analysis
slides.content:
# What-If Analysis

## Sensitivity Testing

```
Question: What if sales drop 10%?
Analysis: Recalculate all affected budgets
```

## Scenario Analysis

| Scenario | Assumptions |
|----------|-------------|
| Best case | Optimistic |
| Base case | Most likely |
| Worst case | Pessimistic |

## Break-Even Sensitivity

```
How much can volume drop
before reaching break-even?

Margin of safety = Current - BE / Current
```
